revision.text:
The '''International Congress on Medieval Studies''' is an annual [[academic conference]] held for [[scholars]] specializing in, or with an interest in, [[medieval studies]]. It is sponsored by [[Western Michigan University]] in [[Kalamazoo, Michigan]] and is held during the first half of May. The Congress is the largest annual gathering in the field, regularly attracting over three thousand registered participants.<ref>{{cite news | first = Kristen | last = Shamus | title = Education in every direction| publisher = [[Detroit Free Press]]| date = June 3, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Meehan | last = Chris | title = Medievalists make annual Kalamazoo pilgrimage | publisher = [[Kalamazoo Gazette]] | date = May 3, 2006}}</ref> The 50th annual conference took place in 2015.
== History == In 1962, the newly established Institute for Medieval Studies at Western Michigan University organized a biennial gathering known as the Conference on Medieval Studies. By 1970, participation had grown significantly and the gathering was made an annual affair. Unusual for the time, the organizers issued [[call for papers|calls for papers]] which were open to all in the field who were interested, including graduate students (see '''Scope and Participation''', below).<ref name="History">{{cite web | url = http://www.wmich.edu/medieval/about-us/history.html | accessdate = June 18, 2007 | title = A Brief History of the Medieval Institute | publisher = Western Michigan University | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080719105950/http://www.wmich.edu/medieval/about-us/history.html | archivedate = July 19, 2008 | df = }}</ref> In the program of the 50th Congress, John Sommerfeldt reminisces about the inception of the humble conference as a place where "bright young scholars could be heard."<ref>Sommerfeldt, John (2015), "A Remembrance," ''50th International Congress on Medieval Studies'' Western Michigan University (xxii).</ref> The torch, as Sommerfeldt puts it, has been carried respectably by subsequent directors of the Medieval Institute of Western Michigan University, with increasing numbers of participants and insightful new approaches to medieval studies. The directors, following John Sommerfeldt, include [[Otto Gründler]], [[Paul E. Szarmach]], [[James M. Murray]], and the newly appointed [[Jana Schulman]].
In 1973, the Institute for [[Cistercian]] Studies was established at Western Michigan, and began to hold its annual Cistercian Studies Conference as a sub-set of the International Congress on Medieval Studies.<ref name=History />
The [[Medieval Academy of America]] has held its annual meetings at the Congress in 1974 and 1982.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.medievalacademy.org/annualmeetings/annualmeetingpast.htm | publisher = Medieval Academy of America | accessdate = June 18, 2007 | title = Medieval Academy of America Past Annual Meetings | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927192204/http://www.medievalacademy.org/annualmeetings/annualmeetingpast.htm | archivedate = September 27, 2007 | df = }}</ref> The Academy began sponsoring a [[plenary session]] in 1992 and maintains a committee for this purpose.<ref name=History /><ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.medievalacademy.org/committees/committee_kalamazoo.htm | publisher = Medieval Academy of America | accessdate = June 18, 2007 | title = Medieval Academy of America Kalamazoo Program Committee}}</ref>
== Structure == The Congress is typically held during the first or second week of May, and runs from Thursday morning through Sunday afternoon.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.wmich.edu/medieval/congress/ | title = International Congress on Medieval Studies | accessdate = June 14, 2007 | work = Medieval Institute | publisher = [[Western Michigan University]]}}</ref> Most events are held on the West Campus of Western Michigan University.
An [http://www.wmich.edu/medieval/Assets/pdf/congress/Thurs07.pdf excerpt]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} from the schedule of the 42nd International Congress on Medieval studies, held in May 2007, illustrates the structure and events of the Congress as described below.
=== Sessions === Sessions form the bulk of the activity at the Congress.<ref name = "Schedule">{{cite web | url = http://www.wmich.edu/medieval/Assets/pdf/congress/Thurs07.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = June 14, 2007 | title = 42nd International Congress on Medieval Studies Schedule for May 9th and 10th | publisher = Western Michigan University}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> There are three main types of sessions: *The vast majority of sessions are '''presentations of research'''. These sessions typically consist of between two and four presentations given by scholars in the field who present papers or other updates on the findings of their current research. Each of these sessions is organized around a theme under which the constituent presentations fit. *A minority of sessions are organized as '''roundtable discussions''', in which a discussion on a predetermined topic takes place in at least a partially spontaneous manner. Short, prepared presentations are sometimes given as part of the roundtable. *A few sessions are organized as '''workshops''', in which attendees are active participants. These focus on the teaching and practice of new skills.
Many sessions have a sponsoring group, although individuals or the Congress may organize sessions. Many of the sessions are sponsored by academic associations, universities, or publishers, while others are arranged by ''ad hoc'' groups which are interested in a particular topic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wmich.edu/medieval/Assets/pdf/congress/Sponsor_Index.pdf |title=42nd International Congress on Medieval Studies Index of Sponsoring Organizations |accessdate=June 14, 2007 |publisher=Western Michigan University |format=PDF }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
Approximately six hundred sessions are held across twelve different time slots during the four days. Each session is scheduled to last ninety minutes.
=== Plenary Lectures === Two plenary lectures are given during the conference, at the beginning of the day on Friday and Saturday.
=== Exhibits Hall === The exhibits hall is open during the length of the Congress, and is composed primarily of book publishers selling their latest titles in the field of medieval studies. A minority of the hall also features handcrafts, music, and foodstuffs for sale. In 2007, approximately seventy exhibitors participated.<ref name="WMUNews">{{cite web | url = http://www.wmich.edu/wmu/news/2007/05/010.html | title = More than 3,000 expected to attend medieval congress | work = WMU News | publisher = Western Michigan University | accessdate = June 14, 2007 | date = May 4, 2007}}</ref>
=== Meetings === The Congress serves as a rare chance for international societies of medieval specialists to gather in person, and dozens of business meetings are conducted during breaks between sessions. Many groups use the opportunity to plan for their presentations later in the summer at the [[International Medieval Congress]] held at [[Leeds University]].
=== Entertainment and Attractions === The Congress typically features a film festival, screening movies which have a medieval setting or theme. There are also performances of medieval music and theater.<ref name=WMUNews /><ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.wmich.edu/wmu/news/2004/0404/0304-359.html | title = Medieval congress draws scholars from around world| work = WMU News | publisher = Western Michigan University | accessdate = June 18, 2007 | date = April 29, 2004}}</ref><ref name="WMUNews2">{{cite web | url= http://www.wmich.edu/wmu/news/2003/0305/0203-329.html | title = Medievalists make annual pilgrimage to Kalamazoo| work = WMU News | publisher = Western Michigan University | accessdate = June 18, 2007 | date = May 2, 2003}}</ref>
Some participating organizations sponsor social gatherings in the form of wine hours or open bar receptions.
There are also demonstrations, to foster an understanding of material culture, that vary from year to year. Past demonstrations have included a trebuchet, a longboat, and most recently, a demonstration of blacksmithing.
The annual meeting of medievalists corresponds with the nesting of swans at Goldsworth pond, located at the very heart of the conference. Most years Congress ends before the eggs have hatched, but the 50th Congress was late enough that medievalists got to enjoy watching the cygnets get their sea legs. [[File:Swan nest.JPG|thumb|Swan nest at Goldsworth Pond.]] [[File:Swans and cygnets.JPG|thumb|Swans and cygnets at the 50th International Congress on Medieval Studies.]]
== Scope and Participation == The Congress is very broad in scope, being open to all topics related to the medieval period and to participants from any background. This has served to set it apart from other meetings in the field.<ref name=WMUNews2 /> Topics may range from discussions of [[mysticism]], [[numismatics]], and medieval [[Latin]], to modern medieval-themed video games, the works of [[J. R. R. Tolkien]], and the teaching of medieval studies in the classroom.
Such being the case, participants come from a broad variety of educational backgrounds. Most are professors and graduate students, but a significant minority is composed of architects, monks, undergraduate students, fiction authors, and other independent scholars and enthusiasts. Presenters are not necessarily experts in medieval history; scholars of literature, theater, religion, and art frequently give presentations.<ref name=Schedule />
==See also== *[[Conferences in Medieval Studies]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.wmich.edu/medieval/congress/ International Congress on Medieval Studies] *[http://www.medievalists.net/academia/international-congress-on-medieval-studies/ Section on the Congress from Medievalists.net, with reports from previous years]
{{Western Michigan University}} {{Midwestern U.S. historical societies}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:International Congress On Medieval Studies}} [[Category:History organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Medievalists]] [[Category:Medieval studies]] [[Category:Western Michigan University]]

[[File:June Leavitt.jpg|thumbnail|June Leavitt]] '''June Leavitt''' (born 1950, New York) is an American-Israeli scholar of [[Franz Kafka]] and author of a number of books, both academic and literary, including ''The Mystical Life of Franz Kafka: Theosophy, Cabala and the Modern Spiritual Revival'',<ref>{{cite book|last=Leavitt|first=June|title=The Mystical Life of Franz Kafka: Theosophy, Cabala and the Modern Spiritual Revival|year=2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=0199827834|pages=224}}</ref> and ''Esoteric Symbols: The Tarot in Yeats, Eliot and Kafka<ref>{{cite book|last=Leavitt|first=June|title=Esoteric Symbols: The Tarot in Yeats, Eliot and Kafka|year=2007|publisher=University Press of America|location=Lanham, Maryland|isbn=0761836748|pages=154}}</ref>''. Leavitt has published two novels, including ''The Flight to Seven Swan Bay'',<ref>{{cite book|last=Leavitt|first=June|title=The Flight to Seven Swan Bay|year=1985|publisher=Feldheim|location=Nanuet, New York|isbn=0873063872}} (1985)</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Leavitt|first=June|title=Flight to Seven Swan Bay|year=2011|publisher=Feldheim Publishers|location=New York|isbn=9780873063814}}</ref> for young adults, and ''Falling Star'', the latter of which has been translated into Hebrew (as<ref>{{cite book|last=Leavitt|first=June|title=כוכב נופל|year=1999|publisher=Aviv Publishing|location=Tel Aviv}}</ref> כוכב נופל). Fragments of her autobiographical work, which first appeared in ''[https://www.usnews.com/usnews/news/articles/940418/archive_012744.htm US News and World Report]'', have been translated into Hebrew, French (as ''Vivre a Hebron''<ref>{{cite book|last=Leavitt|first=June|title=Vivre a Hebron|year=1995|publisher=Editions Robert Laffont|location=Paris|isbn=2221082443|pages=307}}</ref>), and German (as ''Hebron, Westjordanland: Im Labyrinth des Terrors''<ref>{{cite book|last=Leavitt|first=June|title=Hebron, Westjordanland: Im Labyrinth des Terrors|year=1996|publisher=Claassen|location=Hildesheim|isbn=3546001044}}</ref>).
Leavitt's memoir, ''Storm of Terror: A Hebron Mother's Diary''<ref>{{cite book|last=Leavitt|first=June|title=Storm of Terror: A Hebron Mother's Diary|year=2002|publisher=Ivan R. Dee|location=Lanham, Maryland|isbn=1566634679|pages=160}}</ref> documents her life and the lives of her family members and friends under [[terrorism]] in the [[West Bank]], beginning in the year 2000 in the midst of Stage II of the [[First Intifada]]. The book received positive reviews in the ''[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2002-10-27/entertainment/0210260008_1_al-aqsa-intifada-west-bank-haim-watzman Chicago Tribune]'' (2002) and the [http://www.jewishjournal.com/arts/article/mother_weathers_terrors_storm_20021004 ''Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles''] (2002), among other reviewers and publications. Leavitt's published diary entries and autobiographical writings led to a critical study of her work by Tamara Neuman in 2006 in a volume entitled, ''Struggle and Survival in the Modern Middle East<ref>{{cite book|last=Burke and David Nejde Yaghoubian|first=Edmund|title=Struggle And Survival In The Modern Middle East|year=2005 (1st edition)/2006 (2nd edition)|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley and London|isbn=0520246616|pages=434}}</ref>''.
Her articles and journalistic writings have been published in the ''[https://www.nytimes.com/2002/08/01/opinion/in-Hebron-death-and-life.html New York Times]'' and the [https://www.usnews.com/usnews/news/articles/940418/archive_012744.htm ''U.S. News & World Report''].
Leavitt's scholarly article, "The Influence of Medieval Rabbinical Commentators on the Countess of Pembroke" was first published in ''[[Notes and Queries]]'' (2003)<ref>{{cite journal|last=Leavitt|first=June|title=The Influence of Medieval Rabbinical Commentators on the Countess of Pembroke|journal=Oxford Journals|year=2003}}</ref> and republished in ''[[Ashgate Publishing|Ashgate Critical Essays on Women Writers in England]]'' (2009).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Leavitt|first=June|title=The Influence of Medieval Rabbinical Commentators on the Countess of Pembroke|journal=Ashgate's Critical Essays on Women Writers in England|year=2009|volume=2|series=1550-1700}}</ref> Her graduate research led to the publication of ''Esoteric Symbols: The Tarot in Yeats, Eliot and Kafka'' (2007) by the [[University Press of America]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Leavitt|first=June|title=Esoteric Symbols: The Tarot in Yeats, Eliot and Kafka|year=2007|publisher=University Press of America|location=Lanham, Maryland|isbn=0761836748|pages=154}}</ref> and ''The Mystical Life of Franz Kafka: Theosophy, Cabala and the Modern Spiritual Revival'' (2011) by [[Oxford University Press]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Leavitt|first=June|title=The Mystical Life of Franz Kafka: Theosophy, Cabala and the Modern Spiritual Revival|year=2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=0199827834|pages=224}}</ref> Her most recent ''The Mystical Life of Franz Kafka: Theosophy, Cabala and the Modern Spiritual Revival'' has been called "original," "pathbreaking," and, according to the ''[http://www.the-tls.co.uk/tls/public/article1119440.ece Times Literary Supplement]'', "Leavitt trawls [Kafka's] oeuvre to find examples of mystical experiences and out-of-body states."<ref>{{cite news|last=Josipovici|first=Gabriel|title=Why we don’t understand Kafka|url=http://www.the-tls.co.uk/tls/public/article1119440.ece|accessdate=29 December 2012|newspaper=Times Literary Supplement|date=5 September 2012}}</ref>
In addition, Leavitt lectures on the subjects of [[Jewish mystical tradition]] and spirituality in literature at [http://www.bgu.ac.il Ben-Gurion University of the Negev] in Be'er Sheva, Israel and has been on the [http://www.aarweb.org/meetings/annual_meeting/program_units/PUinformation.asp?PUNum=AARPU038 Mysticism Group board] at the [[American Academy of Religion]] since 2006. From 2006 to 2009, Leavitt was an active member of the [http://www.asja.org/index.php [[American Society of Journalists and Authors]]]. She has lectured on the subjects of ancient Judaism, mystical experience, Cabala, the poetry of [[William Butler Yeats]] and [[T.S. Eliot]], and the works of Franz Kafka in [http://www.esswe.org/#agenda/ase-third-international-conference-nature-religion-and-esotericism.html South Carolina], [http://www.aarweb.org/meetings/annual_meeting/Past_and_Future_Meetings/2008/default.asp?ANum=&DayTime=&KeyWord=Leavitt&Submit=View+Program+Book#results Chicago], Boston, Atlanta, and New York at various institutes and universities.
Leavitt has five children and lives with her husband in [[Kiryat Arba]].
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Leavitt, June}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Judaic studies]] [[Category:People from Kiryat Arba]]

revision.comment: Nominated for deletion; see [[:Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/KnowHow2GO]]. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
<!-- Please do not remove or change this AfD message until the discussion has been closed. --> {{Article for deletion/dated|page=KnowHow2GO|timestamp=20181105195606|year=2018|month=November|day=5|substed=yes|help=off}} <!-- Once discussion is closed, please place on talk page: {{Old AfD multi|page=KnowHow2GO|date=5 November 2018|result='''keep'''}} --> <!-- End of AfD message, feel free to edit beyond this point --> '''KnowHow2GO''' is a 2007 national [[public service announcement]] campaign focusing on access to [[university|universities and colleges]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasfaa.org/publications/2007/anhelpingcollegedreamsbecomereality011807.html |title=Helping College Dreams Become Reality - NASFAA Promotes Launch Of KnowHow2Go Campaign |accessdate=2007-09-07 |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929015013/http://www.nasfaa.org/publications/2007/anhelpingcollegedreamsbecomereality011807.html |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acenet.edu/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Press_Releases2&TEMPLATE=/CM/ContentDisplay.cfm&CONTENTID=19681 |title=Lumina Foundation, American Council on Education, and the Ad Council Launch Unique College Access Campaign |accessdate=2007-09-07 |format= |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928075430/http://www.acenet.edu/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Press_Releases2&TEMPLATE=%2FCM%2FContentDisplay.cfm&CONTENTID=19681 |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }}</ref> from The [[Advertising Council]], the [[American Council on Education]] and [[Lumina Foundation for Education]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.luminafoundation.org/newsroom/newsletter/Jan2007/knowhow2go.html |title=KnowHow2GO: College-access campaign informed by research |accessdate=2007-09-07 |work= }}</ref> and produced without charge by [[Publicis]] New York.<ref>{{cite news | first=Nicole |last=Smith |authorlink=|coauthors= | title=Ad Council launches KnowHow2Go campaign |url=http://www.dmnews.com/cms/dm-sectors/nonprofits-fundraising/39776.html |work=News Item |publisher=DMNews.com |date=2007-01-24 |accessdate=2007-09-07 }} </ref>
The campaign was designed to raise awareness about the steps needed to prepare for college and to motivate low-income, first-generation students to turn their dreams of going to college into a reality.
== References == <references/>
== External links == *[http://www.knowhow2go.org/ KnowHow2GO.org] *[http://knowhow2gonebraska.org/ KnowHow2GO Nebraska] Many states have partnered with organizations to help sponsor this national campaign. In Nebraska, KnowHow2GO is sponsored by the EducationQuest Foundation and launched pep rallies and other activities for middle school students to learn about college. Along with these activities EducationQuest has a team to launch this campaign in Spanish. * [http://www.KnowHow2GOky.com KnowHow2GO Kentucky] Kentucky's [[KnowHow2GOKy]] program expands the reach to include college access information for all adult audiences. These audiences include transfer students, returning adult students, GED students and college transfer students. * [http://www.knowhow2gocalifornia.org/ KnowHow2GO California] * [http://knowhow2goct.org/ KnowHow2GO Connecticut] * [http://knowhow2goillinois.org/ KnowHow2GO Illinois] * [http://knowhow2goindiana.org/ KnowHow2GO Indiana]
[[Category:Public service announcements of the United States]] [[Category:Education in the United States]]
{{advertising-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox project | name = Kretzmann Commission Report | logo = | image = | caption = Kretzmann Commission Report | mission_statement = ''to survey and study the task of theological education in the Churches related to the College Society'' | commercial = no | type = | products = | location = [[Rajahmundry]] | country = [[India]] | owner = Board of Governors, [[Andhra Christian Theological College]] | founder = [[The Reverend|The Rev.]] M. L. Kretzmann, [[D.D.]], Secretary for planning, study and research, Department of World Missions of the [[Lutheran World Federation]] ([[Convenor]]), | key_people =[[The Reverend|The Rev.]] [[K. Devasahayam]],
[[The Reverend|The Rev.]] [[A. B. Masilamani]],
[[The Right Reverend|The Rt. Rev.]] C. S. Sundaresan | established = {{Start date|1969|10|25|df=y}} | disestablished = {{End date|1969|11|29|df=y}} | funding = [[World Council of Churches]] and the [[Lutheran Church in America]] | budget = | current_status = | website = }} '''The Kretzmann Commission'''Raymond Brady Williams, ''Christian Pluralism in the United States: The Indian Immigrant Experience'', Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1996, p.291. [https://books.google.com/books?id=w1uk6zZQKzAC&lpg=PA291&ots=_fY_9MDmnR&dq=kretzmann%20commission&pg=PR6#v=onepage&q&f=false]''Theological Education in Andhra Pradesh - The Kretzmann Commission Report'', Printed by A. Nageswara Rao at Saraswathi Power Press, Rajahmundry, 1970. [http://115.115.194.213/W27/Result/w27AcptRslt.aspx?AID=80030&xF=T&xD=0&nS=2] was constituted in 1969 by the Board of Governors of the [[Andhra Christian Theological College]], [[Hyderabad]] to, {{quote|survey and study the task of theological education in the Churches related to the College Society}} These [[ecclesiastical]] societies related to the College society at that point of time (1969) included: * [[South Andhra Lutheran Church]] Society, * [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches]] Society, * [[Methodist Church in India|Methodist Church of South Asia]] Society, * [[Convention of Baptist Churches of Northern Circars]] Society, * [[Church of South India]] Society (Dioceses of [[Diocese of Dornakal|Dornakal]], [[Krishna-Godavari Diocese|Krishna-Godavari]], [[Diocese of Medak|Medak]], and [[Diocese of Rayalaseema|Rayalaseema]]The Diocese of Karimnagar came into existence only in 1978. * [[Church of India, Pakistan, Burma, and Ceylon]] Society, Diocese of [[Diocese of Nandyal|Nandyal]]The Diocese of Nandyal was under the ecclesiastical purview of the Anglican Church and later the Church of North India at the time of formation of the College.[https://books.google.co.in/books?id=O_hq6JUSLToC&lpg=PA176&dq=diocese%20of%20nandyal%20church%20of%20north%20india&pg=PA176#v=onepage&q=diocese%20of%20nandyal%20church%20of%20north%20india&f=false] * [[Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church]] Society The Commission Report was tabled before the Board of Governors of the College Society which eventually led to the buildingJames A. Bergquist, P. Kambar Manickam, ''The Crisis of Dependency in Third World Ministries: A Critique of Inherited Missionary Forms in India'', Christian Literature Society, Madras, 1976, pp. 50, 63.[https://books.google.com/books?id=HPEcAAAAMAAJ&dq=kretzmann+commission&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=kretzmann] up of curriculum-intensive courses and the equipping of the [[Seminarians]] with capacities to lead the [[Christian Church|Church]] in [[Andhra Pradesh]] and [[Telangana]]. Theological education took an upward rise with the Kretzmann Commission Report. The Kretzmann Commission was enabled with the assistance of the Theological Education Fund of the [[World Council of Churches]] and the Board of World Missions of the [[Lutheran Church in America]]. The Secretary of the Board of Governors, [[W. D. Coleman]] on behalf of the Board of Governors published a 1,000 copies to be circulated among the Churches in [[Andhra Pradesh]] and [[Telangana]]. A couple of years before the Kretzmann Commission was constituted, [[Seminarians]] deliberated on the Church's mission with special reference to [[Andhra Pradesh]] and [[Telangana]]. In 1966, a graduate thesis was undertaken by a candidate studying at [[Serampore College]], [[Serampore]] entitled ''The Hebrew Concept of 'Righteousness' as proclaimed by the 8th century Prophets and its implications for the Church's mission in [[Andhra Pradesh]]''G. Babu Rao, ''The Hebrew Concept of 'Righteousness' as proclaimed by the 8th century Prophets and its implications for the Church's mission in [[Andhra Pradesh]]'', an unpublished graduate thesis presented to the [[Senate of Serampore College (University)]] in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the Bachelor of Divinity degree, Serampore, 1966. ==Commission members== * [[The Reverend|The Rev.]] M. L. Kretzmann, [[D.D.]], Secretary for planning, study and research, Department of World Missions of the [[Lutheran World Federation]] (Convenor), * [[The Reverend|The Rev.]] [[K. Devasahayam]], [[M.A.]], [[Bachelor of Divinity|B.D.]] ([[Hon.]]), [[S.T.M.]], [[Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church]], * [[The Reverend|The Rev.]] [[A. B. Masilamani]], [[M.A.]], [[Th.M.]], [[Convention of Baptist Churches of Northern Circars]], * [[The Right Reverend|The Rt. Rev.]] C. S. Sundaresan, [[Bishop]] - in - [[Diocese of Rayalaseema|Rayalaseema]], [[Church of South India]] ==Findings== The Commission members met during various points of time during the latter half of 1969, first on 25 October 1969 to draw up a plan and again a month later during 26–29 November to summarize its findings. The members of the Commission met at different places for visitation and consultation. As part of field visits, the members had been to, * Hindustan Bible Institute, [[Chennai]], * [[Mennonite Brethren Centenary Bible College]], [[Shamshabad]], * [[St. John's Regional Seminary|St. John's Regional Seminary (Theologiate)]], [[Ramanthapur]], * [[Ramayapatnam]] Baptist Theological Seminary, [[Ramayapatnam]], * Lutheran Bible Training Institute, [[Rajahmundry]]. In addition, the members of the Commission also had special consultations with [[Canon Emani Sambayya]], [[Dr.]] P. David [[Ph.D.]] ([[Yale University|Yale]]) and [[The Reverend|Rev.]] Erik W. Nielsen. As for the background material, the Commission members accessed scholarly action reports relating to the [[Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church]] Society, especially the papers of [[B. V. Subbamma]], [[S. W. Schmitthenner]], [[W. P. Peery]] and James A. Bergquist, the papers of the [[Board of Theological Education of the Senate of Serampore College]], the [[National Council of Churches in India]] and other papers. The Commission took cognizance of the concerns of the Church in [[Andhra Pradesh]] ([[Telangana]] included). The Commission also devised a structured questionnaire for use among two kinds of respondents, the Church Leaders and the Old Students, during field visits. ==Outcome== At the very outset, the Commission recommended for [[Indian people|Indian]] Teachers to be placed in Seminaries to take up theological curriculum, especially for the core subjects in theology. The Commission further recommended that theological education broaden its horizons in keeping up with the changing times. Based on the recommendations of the Commission, the [[Andhra Christian Theological College]] did away with the erstwhile [[Licentiate in Theology]] programme and embarked on two graduate programmes, namely, the [[Bachelor of Theology]] and the [[Bachelor of Divinity]] degrees. As part of the curruculum study, the Commission Members foresaw the need to include [[Worship]], Social Analysis, [[Inter-faith]], [[gender]] concerns, [[inculturation]], [[Psychology]], Language [[Usability]], personal devotion, [[Sociology]] and many other inter-disciplinary courses. In the ensuing [[decade]], the Faculty Members were able to upgrade their academics at national and international [[Universities]] and returned to teach in the College who include, * [[Gaddala Solomon|G. Solomon]], [[Th.M.]] ([[Palmer Theological Seminary|Eastern]]),G. Solomon, ''The concept of Suffering in the Bible and in Hinduism'', Eastern University, King of Prussia, 1957.[http://www.worldcat.org/title/concept-of-suffering-in-the-bible-and-in-hinduism/oclc/13351098] * K. Prasada Rao, [[M.Th.]] ([[Senate of Serampore College (University)|Serampore]]) * K. Wilson,K. Wilson, ''Culture and Conversion: An Analytical Study of the Interaction between Western Theology and Eastern Culture through the Christian Missions in the Indian Sub-Continent'', Syracuse University, Syracuse, 1972.[http://surface.syr.edu/rel_etd/54/] [[Th.M.]] ([[Duke University|Duke]]), [[Ph.D.]] ([[University of Syracuse|Syracuse]])Though Wilson returned to teach at the College after his doctoral studies, he preferred to teach [[Philosophy]] at the state-run [[Osmania University]]. ''Indian Journal of Philosophic Studies'', Volume 1, Issue 1, 1974, p. 53.[https://books.google.com/books?id=y9JRs6SJyGMC&dq=kothapalli+wilson+osmania+university&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=kothapalli+wilson] * [[Victor Premasagar]], [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] ([[Cantab.]]), [[Ph.D.]] ([[St. Andrews University|St. Andrews]]) * [[William Powlas Peery]], [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] ([[Vanderbilt University|Vanderbilt]]), [[Ph.D.]] ([[Duke University|Duke]]) * [[Suppogu Joseph|S. Joseph]], [[M.Th.]] ([[Senate of Serampore College (University)|Serampore]], [[D.Th.]] ([[Senate of Serampore College (University)|Serampore]]) * [[Eric J. Lott]], [[M.Litt.]] ([[University of Lancaster|Lancaster]]), [[Ph.D.]] ([[University of Lancaster|Lancaster]]) * [[Ryder Devapriam]], [[Th.M.]] ([[McCormick Theological Seminary|McCormick]]), [[Th.D.]] ([[General Theological Seminary|GTS]]) * [[Muriel Spurgeon Carder]], [[Th.M.]] ([[Union Theological Seminary in the city of New York|Union]]), [[Th.D.]] ([[Toronto University|Toronto]]) * [[R. R. Sundara Rao]], [[M.A.]] ([[Venkateshwara University|Venkateshwara]]), [[Ph.D.]] ([[Wisconsin University|Wisconsin]]) * [[Ravela Joseph|R. Joseph]], [[Th.M.]] ([[Andover Newton Theological School|Andover]]), [[M.Th.]] ([[Senate of Serampore College (University)|Serampore]]) * [[M. Victor Paul]], [[M.Th.]] ([[Senate of Serampore College (University)|Serampore]]), [[Th.M.]] ([[Luther Seminary|Luther]]), [[D.Min.]] ([[Luther Seminary|Luther]]) * K. David, [[M.Th.]] ([[Senate of Serampore College (University)|Serampore]]), [[M.A.]] ([[University of Calcutta|Calcutta]]), [[Ph.D.]] ([[Edinburgh]]){{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=998XAQAAIAAJ&q=komaravalli+david&dq=komaravalli+david&hl=en&sa=X&ei=4riRVZiWApWLuATpy6l4&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAQ |title=Contributors (?) |work=University of Edinburgh Journal}} Many of these Teachers also played a role at the [[Senate of Serampore College (University)]] and subsequent curriculum revisions at the University level. In 1985, a [[Content analysis]] of theological [[syllabi]] being taught at the [[Seminaries]] in the country was undertaken by the Christian Institute for the Study of Religion and Society, [[Bangalore]]. The [[New Testament]] Scholar M. V. Abraham and the [[Old Testament]] Scholar G. Babu Rao,G. Babu Rao, "Content Analysis of Theological Syllabi – Old Testament" in ''Religion and Society'', Christian Institute for the Study of Religion and Society, Bangalore, 1985. [https://books.google.com/books?um=1&q=g.babu+rao+doctoral+studies&btnG=Search+Books] the former being associated with the Leonard Theological College, [[Jabalpur]] and the latter associated with the [[Bible Society of India]] in [[Translations]] were given the task of finding out the extent of theological [[syllabi]] using the [[statistical]] [[tool]] of [[Content analysis]]. Similarly, a research on the theological education in India was also undertaken by [[Siga Arles]] in the [[nineties]] at the [[University of Aberdeen]] and its findings were published with the title ''Theological education for the mission of the church in India, 1947–1987: theological education in relation to the identification of the task of mission and the development of ministries in India, 1947-1987, with special reference to the Church of South India''Siga Arles, ''Theological education for the mission of the church in India, 1947–1987: theological education in relation to the identification of the task of mission and the development of ministries in India, 1947–1987, with special reference to the Church of South India'', Peter Lang, Frankfurt, 1990. [https://books.google.com/books?id=7XnYAAAAMAAJ&q=siga+arles+theological+education&dq=siga+arles+theological+education&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj4k6GS0uPKAhXEt44KHWlxDTsQ6AEIGzAA] which was published in 1990 by Peter Lang, [[Frankfurt]]. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Protestant ecumenism]] [[Category:Church of South India]] [[Category:Convention of Baptist Churches of Northern Circars]] [[Category:Senate of Serampore College (University)]] [[Category:Christianity studies]]

[[File:Bode Museum marfil bizantino. 21.JPG|thumb|Christ between St. Peter and St. Paul]] [[File:Bode Museum marfil bizantino. 22.JPG|thumb|The Virgin crowning an Emperor, assisted by the archangel Gabriel]] The '''Leo Scepter''' is a [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] [[ivory]] work of art, usually and erroneously identified as a scepter tip.<ref>Cutler, Anthony. "The Hand of The Master: Craftsmanship, Ivory, and Society in Byzantium (9th-11th Centuries)" ''Princeton University Press''. Princeton, NJ. 1994.</ref> Generally accepted to be from the 9th century, the piece is now part of the collection of the [[Berlin State Museums]]. It must be added that the date and identification of this ivory, although probable, are not indisputable. Various historians have suggested that the piece, carved with religious [[iconographies]] and inscriptions, such as the name of an [[Emperor]] Leo, had been made during the reign of [[Leo VI the Wise]] ({{reign|886–912}}), and was probably handled in public ceremonies as a symbol of imperial and religious authority.<ref>Corrigan, Kathleen. "The Ivory Scepter of Leo VI: A Statement of Post-Iconoclastic Imperial Ideology". The Art Bulletin, Vol.60, No.3. 1978. Pp 407-416. </ref> [[Kurt Weitzmann]] on the other hand proposed that this ivory may have been made during the reign of [[Leo V the Armenian]] ({{reign|813–820}}). However, a recent analysis of the content of its inscriptions has shown that the connection with the coronation of Leo V is unjustified.<ref name="Cutler200">Cutler, Anthony."The Hand of The Master: Craftmanship, Ivory, and Society in Byzantium (9th-11th centuries)" p. 200.</ref>
==Original function== Scholars have argued about the original function of this ivory, whether it was the tip of a scepter, or the grip on the lid of a casket containing a crown. However, recent scholars have argued that the ivory was in fact a ceremonial comb made probably for the Emperor [[Leo VI the Wise|Leo VI]].<ref>Stephenson, Paul. "Byzantine World". New York. ed. Routledge. 2010. p. 305. </ref>
==Significance== The Leo Ivory is the largest known ivory work of art made under the [[Macedonian Renaissance]]. It measures 10.2 x 10.0 x 2.1 centimeters, and it is carved in all four sides. The piece contains a dowel hole measuring 3.2 centimeters into its base, which some experts have suggested was perhaps attached to something else, and was designed to be handled.<ref name="Cutler200"/>
==Manufacture== While references in Byzantine texts to ivory after the sixth century are few, various historians have suggested that early Christian ivories such as the ivory plaque with the coronation of Emperor Leo VI's son, [[Constantine VII]] Prophyrogenitos, were made in an urgent effort to erase their peasant origins from the public memory, to legitimate the power of the Macedonian dynasty, and to communicate to the Byzantine society the ideology that their kingship was the will of God.<ref>Cormack, Robin. "Byzantine Art". Oxford History of Art. Oxford University Press. 2000. p. 134.</ref> The scarcity of ivory in the area, and its significance in the art of the Byzantine Empire and Church certainly encouraged its production.<ref>Osborn, Harold and Antonia Bostrom. "Ivories". ''The Oxford Companion to western Art''. Ed. Hugh Brigstocke. ''Oxford Art Online''. Oxford University Press. Web. </ref>
==Physical description== The iconography carved in the front of the comb represents Christ in the center, surrounded by St. [[Saint Peter|Peter]] on his left and St. [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]] on his right. The iconography on the back represents the Virgin [[Mary, mother of Jesus|Mary]] crowning an Emperor, probably Leo VI, and assisted by the angel [[Gabriel]]. By this image of coronation, various experts have suggested the explicit willingness to show the divine approval of the imperial power on earth. Others have suggested that the ceremonial comb was made perhaps in order to celebrate the coronation of the Emperor Leo VI. However, due to the significance of the [[Psalms]] in the [[Byzantine liturgy]] of [[Pentecost]], the three inscriptions bearing the Psalms 20 and 44 suggest that the comb was made perhaps for the celebration of [[Pentecost]]. The arches, niches, and windows carved on the ivory suggest a striking resemblance with the interior architecture of the east end of the [[Hagia Sophia]] cathedral.<ref>Evans, Helen C. and William D. Wixom. "The Glory of Byzantium: Art and Culture of The Middle Byzantine Era'. The Metropolitan Museum of Art. New York. 1997.p. 201.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{more citations needed|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Lil Miquela | image = Miquela Family Tree cropped.png | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = | background = solo_singer | alias = {{hlist|Miquela Sousa|Miquela}} | origin = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[United States]] | genre = {{hlist|[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]|[[electronic music|electronic]]|[[pop music|pop]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|Instagram personality|singer|model}} | instrument = vocals | years_active = 2016–present | label = | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Anamanaguchi]]|[[Baauer]]}} | website = [https://www.instagram.com/lilmiquela/?hl=en Instagram profile] }}
'''Miquela Sousa''', better known as '''Lil Miquela''', is a fictional character created by [[Yung Skeeter|Trevor McFedries]] and Sara Decou as a digital art project.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/brud.fyi/|title=Brud (@brud.fyi) • Instagram photos and videos|website=www.instagram.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-21}}</ref><ref name="Billboard">{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/international/7964899/virtual-instagram-miquela-controversy-interview|title=Virtual It-Singer Miquela Says 'Controversy Doesn't Mean Anything': Interview|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref><ref name="Highsnobiety">{{cite web|last1=Gorsler|first1=Fabian|title=Meet Lil Miquela: Fashion’s First Virtual Instagram Influencer|url=https://www.highsnobiety.com/p/lil-miquela-virtual-influencer-instagram/?format=amp|website=Highsnobiety|accessdate=1 April 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref name="HYPEBEAST">{{cite web|last1=Rouse|first1=Isaac|title=Miquela Sousa Is Fashion's First Computer Generated Influencer|url=https://hypebeast.com/2018/2/miquela-sousa-first-computer-generated-fashion-influencer?amp=1|website=HYPEBEAST|accessdate=1 April 2018|language=en|date=5 February 2018}}</ref><ref name="FN">{{cite web|last1=McDonald|first1=Samantha|title=This Instagram Influencer Is Not Even Human|url=http://footwearnews.com/2018/influencers/technology/miquela-sousa-instagram-virtual-influencer-491637/amp/|website=FN|accessdate=1 April 2018|language=en|date=6 February 2018}}</ref> Miquela is an [[Instagram]] model and music artist claiming to be from [[Downey, California]].
The project began in 2016 as an [[Instagram]] profile. By April 2018, the account had amassed more than a million followers by portraying the lifestyle of an Instagram it-girl over social media.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/lilmiquela-instagram_uk_57c94056e4b085cf1ecdc0af|title=Instagram's Latest 'It' Model Is Confusing The Hell Out Of Everyone|date=2016-09-02|newspaper=The Huffington Post|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref> The account also details a fictional narrative which presents Miquela as a sentient robot in conflict with other digital projects created by McFedries and Decou.
In August 2017, Miquela released her first single, "Not Mine".<ref name="billboard.com">{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7898117/miquela-virtual-singer-instagram-not-mine-song-stream|title=Virtual Singer & Internet Star Miquela Shares Debut Single 'Not Mine'|work=Billboard|access-date=2017-11-05}}</ref> Her pivot into a music has been compared to virtual musicians [[Gorillaz]] and [[Hatsune Miku]].<ref name="Billboard"/>
==Origins== Miquela’s first Instagram post was made on April 22, 2016. The project garnered both intrigue and criticism for the character's digital appearance with fans and online commenters oscillating between positing that Miquela is an art project or a social experiment carried out by a real unidentified woman. Miquela was rumored to be a marketing gimmick for ''[[The Sims]]''.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} British model Emily Bador was rumored to be Miquela, fans citing the character's abundance of freckles. Bador openly acknowledged the physical similarity.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}
==Online presence== Miquela has been pictured with a number of celebrities including [[Diplo]], [[How to Dress Well]], killerandasweetthang founder Eileen Kelly, [[Molly Soda]], [[Nile Rogers]], and [[Samantha Urbani]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/lilmiquela/|title=*~ MIQUELA ~* (@lilmiquela) • Instagram photos and videos|website=www.instagram.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> She has been interviewed and or profiled in a number of publications including Refinery29, Vogue, Buzzfeed, v-files, Nylon, the Guardian, Business of Fashion, The Cut, and BBC.com.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} As well as by Shane Dawson, YouTube celebrity, in a [https://youtube.com/watch?v=NdNYAiU-SLI phone interview]<ref>{{Citation|last=shane|title=CONSPIRACY THEORIES & INTERVIEW WITH LIL MIQUELA|date=2017-09-18|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NdNYAiU-SLI|access-date=2018-10-24}}</ref>. She appeared on the cover of High Snobiety in April 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.highsnobiety.com/p/lil-miquela-cover-story-issue-16/|title=Meet Lil Miquela, the AI Influencer on the Cover of Our New Print Issue|website=High Snobiety|language=en|access-date=2018-08-17}}</ref> In February 2018, Miquela did an Instagram takeover for Prada as part of Milan Fashion Week.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/prada-instagram-gifs-lil-miquela|title=Prada Launches Instagram GIFs With Help From a Fictional It Girl|work=Vogue|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en}}</ref>
===Online narratives=== In April 2018, a trans-media story began to play out on Miquela's Instagram involving [https://www.instagram.com/blawko22 @Blawko22], and [https://www.instagram.com/bermudaisbae/ @BermudaIsBae], two other virtual Instagram accounts who are presented as "sentient robots." The story suggests that two organizations are responsible for the creation of these sentient robots. In the narrative, fictional brand Brud created Miquela and "Blawko22" while competing fictional brand Cain Intelligence created "BermudaIsBae".
On April 17, all of Miquela's Instagram posts were removed. "BermudaIsBae" was purported to have hacked Miquela's account. The two online personas then began posting pictures together as Miquela worked to reclaim the original account.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BhuruzXHetm/?taken-by=bermudaisbae|title=Bermuda on Instagram: "More emotional than I thought it would be. Despite it all, there’s only three of us out there and we need to stick together. We talked it…"|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-04-24}}</ref> After reclaiming the account, Miquela posted a series of notes saying that she is a robot and claiming sentience.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BkjEPEuFdp0/?taken-by=lilmiquela|title=Lil Miquela on Instagram: "So I pull up to the trail and there she is. No rattlesnakes. No hiking. Just a robot sitting on the curb in skinny jeans and wedges. She said it’s the only way she could get my attention since I haven’t answered her texts since we went to the mall a couple weeks back. She just wanted to hang out. So here we are 'hanging out.'"|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-08-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BjvhTbylRcD/?taken-by=lilmiquela|title=Lil Miquela on Instagram: "So, Brud programmed my memories, claiming I’m from a place called Downey. It’s right in-between Los Angeles and Disneyland. Even though that sounds like a dream to me, I had to come check it out for myself..."|website=Instagram|accessdate=2018-08-17}}</ref>
==Music career== Miquela has released several singles since her debut with "Not Mine," including "You Should be Alone," "Over You," and a collaboration with [[Baauer]] titled "Hate Me." Her musical style is characterized by the use of [[auto-tune]] and [[trap music|trap]]-influenced production. Her music has been released on [[YouTube]] and [[Spotify]]. Miquela's sound is purportedly based off of the soundtrack to Sam Raimi's 1981 cult classic, [[Evil Dead]].
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Miquela, Lil}} [[Category:Fictional characters]]

===April=== * ''Landmarks'' – [[Robert Macfarlane (writer)|Robert Macfarlane]] * ''The Story of Alice'' – [[Robert Douglas-Fairhurst]] * ''[[The Shepherd's Life]]'' – [[James Rebanks]] * ''[[Skyfaring: A Journey with a Pilot]]'' – [[Mark Vanhoenacker]] * ''Words Without Music'' – [[Philip Glass]]
===May=== * ''Year of the Fat Knight'' – [[Antony Sher]] * ''The Weather Experiment'' – [[Peter Moore (author)|Peter Moore]] * ''Gold Fever'' – [[Steve Boggan]] * ''Channel Shore'' – [[Tom Fort]] ===June=== * ''Ghettoside'' – [[Jill Leovy]] * ''Adventures in Human Being'' – [[Gavin Francis]] * ''Walking Away'' – [[Simon Armitage]] * ''Keeping an Eye Open'' – [[Julian Barnes]] ===July=== * ''Queen of the Desert'' – [[Georgina Howell]] * ''[[All Day Long: A Portrait of Britain at Work]]'' – [[Joanna Biggs]] * ''Sixty Degrees North'' – [[Malachy Tallack]] * ''On the Move'' – [[Oliver Sacks]] * ''Long Time No See'' – [[Hannah Lowe]]

A '''''longa''''' ({{lang-ar|'''لونجا'''}}) is a Turkish / Eastern European dance, that was later introduced into [[Arabic music]] and is often performed at the end of a ''[[muwashshah]]''.
It generally uses an ''[[iqa']]'' equivalent to 2/4, with several sections called ''khanat''<!--need Arabic script; is it خانت?--> (singular ''khana''),<!--Is the Arabic خانة?--> each followed by a ''[[taslim]]'' ([[refrain]]). The last ''khana'' is generally in 3/4.
A common form of ''longa'' is ''longa Riad in Nahawand scale'' ('''لونجا نهاوند''') which is composed by Riad el-Sonbaty in the ''[[Arabic maqam|maqam]] Nahawand''. ==See also== *[[Syrtos]] *[[Fasıl]] *[[Pop-folk]]
==External links== *[http://www.maqamworld.com/forms.html ''Longa'' page]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Longa (Middle Eastern Music)}}

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Visitor attractions in Kastamonu Province to [[:Category:Tourist attractions in Kastamonu Province]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
[[File:Kastamonu Kasaba Koyu Mahmut Bey Civisiz Camii 1240691 Nevit.jpg|thumb|Roof]] [[File:Kastamonu Kasaba Koyu Mahmut Bey Civisiz Camii 1240149 Nevit.jpg|thumb|Mihrab]] '''Mahmutbey Mosque''' is a historical mosque in [[Kasaba, Kastamonu|Kasaba]] village in [[Kastamonu Province]], [[Turkey]]
Kasaba was once an important settlement in Kastamonu Province. Now it is a small village about {{convert|18|km}} to [[Kastamonu]]. But the historical mosque of the village at {{coord|41|28|48|N|33|41|17|E}} is an important cultural building of the province. ==The mosque== It was commissioned by Mahmut Bey, a member of [[Isfendiyarids|Candarid]] house in 1366. The mosque is unique in its building style for no cement is used in the construction (except for the [[mihrab]]). The roof too was constructed without using any metal element. (In fact it is also known as ''Çivisiz camii'' meaning "mosque without nail") <ref name="KT"/>The plan of the mosque is rectengular. It is one of the first wood columned and wood roofed mosques in Anatolia. The exterior of mosque was constructed by hewn stone. Ceiling of the building stands on four pillars. Inside of the mosque all the wood surfaces decorated with plant-dye ornaments called ''kalem işi'' (literally "pencil work"). <ref name="UN"/>The portal of the mosque which was a masterpiece of art however is now kept in the Kastamonu Museum.<ref name="KT">[http://www.kastamonukultur.gov.tr/TR,93964/mahmutbey-camii.html Ministry of Culture page {{tr icon}}]</ref> A replica of the original portal has been mounted in its place.
==World Heritage Site status== The mosque was added to the tentative list in the cultural category of [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] on April 15, 2014.<ref name="UN">[http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5904/ Unesco page]</ref>
{{Tentative list of World Heritage Sites in Turkey}} {{Mosques in Turkey}}
==References== <references/>
[[Category:History of Kastamonu Province]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Kastamonu Province]] [[Category:Religious buildings completed in 1366]] [[Category:World Heritage Site Tentative list]] [[Category:Mosques in Kastamonu]] [[Category:Candaroğlu]]

{{Infobox person | name = Michael Friedländer | image = Friedlander portrait.png | alt = | caption = Portrait of Michael Friedländer. | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1833|4|29|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Jutrosin|Jutroschin]], [[Grand Duchy of Posen|Posen]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1910|12|10|1833|4|29|mf=y}} | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Michael Friedländer''' (April 29, 1833 – December 10, 1910) was an [[oriental studies|Orientalist]] and principal of [[Jews' College]], [[London]]. He is best known for his [[English language|English]] translation of [[Maimonides]]' ''[[Guide to the Perplexed]]'', which was the most popular such translation until the more recent work of [[Shlomo Pines]], and still remains in print.
==Biography== Friedländer was born at [[Jutrosin|Jutroschin]], in the [[Grand Duchy of Posen]]. His early secular education was at a local [[Catholic school]], and his Jewish education came from attendance of a [[Cheder]], and from his father, who was a [[talmudist]] and [[Hebrew grammarian]]. He then attended the [[Gymnasium (school)|gymnasium]], while continuing his Jewish studies under Rabbi [[Jacob Joseph Oettinger]] and Rabbi [[Elchanan Rosenstein]].
In 1856, he began studies in classical languages and mathematics at the universities of [[University of Berlin|Berlin]] and [[Halle/Saale]] (Ph.D. 1862), and concurrently with his university studies he pursued [[Talmudic]] learning. Settling in Berlin, he was appointed principal of the Talmud school, which position he resigned in 1865 to accept that of principal of Jews' College, London, in succession to [[Barnett Abrahams]]. There he taught theology, biblical and rabbinical exegesis, Talmud, Jewish history, mathematics, and [[Arabic language|Arabic]].
He retired from this position in 1907, and died on December 10, 1910. His son-in-law was [[Moses Gaster]] (1856–1939), the [[Hakham]] of the [[Spanish and Portuguese Jews|Spanish and Portuguese congregation]], [[London]], and a [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] [[Linguistics|linguist]].
==Works== [[Image:Freidlander perplexed.png|thumb|200px|Title page of ''[[The Guide for the Perplexed]]'' by Moses Maimonides, translated from the original Arabic text by '''M. Friedländer''', Ph.D., Pardes Publishing House, 1946.]]
Friedländer displayed considerable literary activity. He authored a few dozen articles for the [[Jewish Encyclopedia]]. As a member of the [[Society of Hebrew Literature]] he published under its auspices: *''The Commentary of [[Abraham ibn Ezra]] on [[Book of Isaiah|Isaiah]]'', translated into English with extensive annotations (available on Google Books) *''An [[Essay]] on the Writings of Ibn Ezra'' *A translation from the original [[Arabic language|Arabic]], with notes, of [[Maimonides]]' ''[[Guide of the Perplexed]]'' (1881). *''The Jewish Religion'' (1890, American edition: 1946) *[[German language|German]] commentary upon the [[Song of Songs]] (1867).
He also edited a ''Jewish Family Bible'' in English and Hebrew, compiled a ''Handbook of the Jewish Religion,'' made calculations on the [[Hebrew calendar]], and contributed articles to the ''[[Jewish Quarterly Review]],'' the ''Dictionary of National Biography,'' and other publications. Numerous papers read by him at Jews' College and elsewhere have been published.
==References== {{Reflist}} *{{Citation | surname=Gaster | given=Theodor | authorlink= Theodor Gaster | year= 1946 | chapter=Dr. Michael Friedländer (a biographical sketch) | editor=Michael Friedländer | title=The Jewish Religion | edition=2nd | publisher=Pardes | place=New York | URL= | accessdate= }} *{{JewishEncyclopedia |first=Richard |last=Gottheil |authorlink=Richard Gottheil |first2=Max |last2=Seligsohn |authorlink2=Max Seligsohn |title=Friedländer, Michael |url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/6380-friedlander-michael }} The JE cites the following works: **Jewish Year Book, 1899; **Jewish Chronicle, May 8, 1903.J
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Friedlander, Michael}} [[Category:1833 births]] [[Category:1910 deaths]] [[Category:People from Jutrosin]] [[Category:Talmudists]] [[Category:Judaic studies]] [[Category:People from the Grand Duchy of Posen]] [[Category:English people of German-Jewish descent]] [[Category:English Jews]] [[Category:London School of Jewish Studies]] [[Category:Humboldt University of Berlin alumni]] [[Category:Martin Luther University of Halle-Wittenberg alumni]] [[Category:Jewish translators of the Bible]] [[Category:Translators of the Bible into English]] [[Category:Translators of the Bible into English who were not native speakers]] [[Category:19th-century translators]]

revision.comment: /* Francophone communities in New England */ clarified population is of the entire community, and NOT the population that speaks french
revision.text:
{{infobox language |name=New England French |nativename=français de Nouvelle-Angleterre |pronunciation= |states= [[United States]]
([[New England]]) (primarily [[Maine]], [[New Hampshire]], and [[Vermont]]) |speakers= {{sigfig|118,000|2}} |date=2001 |ref={{citation needed|date=February 2013}} |familycolor=Indo-European |fam2=[[Italic languages|Italic]] |fam3=[[Romance languages|Romance]] |fam4=[[Western Romance languages|Western]] |fam5=[[Gallo-Romance languages|Gallo-Romance]] |fam6=[[Langues d'oïl|Oïl]] |fam7=[[French language|French]] |fam8=[[Canadian French]] |isoexception=dialect |glotto=none }} '''New England French''' ({{lang-fr|français de Nouvelle-Angleterre}}) is a variety of [[Canadian French]] spoken in the [[New England]] region of the United States.{{cite book |title=Status and Function of Languages and Language Varieties |last= Ammon|first= Ulrich|authorlink= |author2=International Sociological Association |year= 1989|publisher= Walter de Gruyter|location= |isbn= 0899253563|pages= 306–308|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=geh261xgI8sC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=April 3, 2012}} New England French is one of the major forms of the [[French language]] that developed in what is now the United States, the others being [[Louisiana French]] and the nearly extinct [[Missouri French]], [[Muskrat French]] and [[Métis French]]. The dialect is the predominant form of French spoken in New England (apart from standard French), except in the [[Saint John River (Bay of Fundy)|Saint John Valley]] of northern [[Aroostook County, Maine]], where [[Acadian French]] predominates. The dialect is endangered, but its use is supported by bilingual education programs in place since 1987. ==Number of French-speakers by state== {{main|French language in the United States}} The figures below include speakers of any [[French dialect]], as estimated during the 2012-2016 [[American Community Survey]]:{{Cite web| url=https://factfinder.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/ACS/16_5YR/B16001/0100000US.04000| title=Language Spoken at Home by Ability to Speak English for the Population 5 Years and Over (B16001): All States Within United States, 2012-2016 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates| publisher=U.S. Census Bureau American FactFinder| accessdate=April 11, 2018}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! State!! Number of speakers!! Proportion of state's population |- | Maine || 38,695 || 3.06% |- | New Hampshire || 21,260 || 1.68% |- | Vermont || 8,508 || 1.43% |- | Rhode Island || 9,382 || 0.94% |- | Massachusetts || 54,710 || 0.86% |- | Connecticut || 25,828 || 0.76% |} ==Francophone communities in New England== French language spoken at home by more than 10% of the population, as estimated for the 2011-2015 American Community Survey:{{Cite web| url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/ACS/15_5YR/B16001/0400000US23.06000| title=Language Spoken at Home by Ability to Speak English for the Population 5 Years and Over (B16001): All County Subdivisions within Maine, 2011-2015 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates| publisher=U.S. Census Bureau American FactFinder| accessdate=April 12, 2018}}{{Cite web| url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/ACS/15_5YR/B16001/0400000US33.06000| title=Language Spoken at Home by Ability to Speak English for the Population 5 Years and Over (B16001): All County Subdivisions within New Hampshire, 2011-2015 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates| publisher=U.S. Census Bureau American FactFinder| accessdate=April 12, 2018}}{{Cite web| url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/ACS/15_5YR/B16001/0400000US50.06000| title=Language Spoken at Home by Ability to Speak English for the Population 5 Years and Over (B16001): All County Subdivisions within Vermont, 2011-2015 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates| publisher=U.S. Census Bureau American FactFinder| accessdate=April 12, 2018}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Subjects|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2018/01/weodata/weorept.aspx?pr.x=40&pr.y=7&sy=2017&ey=2018&scsm=1&ssd=1&sort=country&ds=.&br=1&c=576&s=NGDPD%2CPPPGDP%2CNGDPDPC%2CPPPPC&grp=0&a=|publisher=[[International utc_offset = +8 | antipodes = | date_format = {{nowrap|dd-mm-yyyy}} | drives_on = [[Right- and left-hand traffic|left]] | calling_code = [[+65]] | iso3166code = SG | cctld = {{hlist|[[.sg]]|[[.新加坡]]|[[.சிங்கப்பூர்]]}} }} '''Singapore''' ({{IPAc-en|audio=En-us-Singapore.ogg|ˈ|s|ɪ|ŋ|(|g|)|ə|p|ɔːr}}), officially the '''Republic of Singapore''' ([[Malay language|Malay]]: {{Native name|ms|Republik Singapura|paren=omit}}; [[Chinese language|Chinese]]: {{Native name|zh|新加坡共和国|italics=off|paren=omit}}; [[Tamil language|Tamil]]: {{Native name|ta|சிங்கப்பூர் குடியரசு|italics=off|paren=omit}}), is a [[sovereignty|sovereign]] [[city-state]] and [[island country]] in [[Southeast Asia]]. It lies one degree ({{Convert|137|km|disp=or}}) north of the [[equator]], at the southern tip of the [[Malay Peninsula]], with [[Indonesia]]'s [[Riau Islands]] to the south and [[Peninsular Malaysia]] to the north. Singapore's territory consists of one [[Pulau Ujong|main island]] along with [[List of islands of Singapore|62 other islets]]. Since independence, extensive [[land reclamation]] has increased its total size by 23% ({{Convert|130|km2|disp=or}}). The country is known for its transition from [[Third World|third world]] to [[First World|first world]] in a single generation, under the leadership of its founding father, [[Lee Kuan Yew]].{{cite news |title=His fighting spirit helped S'pore leap from Third World to First |url= https://www.todayonline.com/rememberinglky/his-fighting-spirit-helped-spore-leap-third-world-first |work=Today |location= Singapore |date=26 March 2015}} [[Stamford Raffles]] founded [[Founding of modern Singapore|colonial Singapore]] in 1819 as a trading post of the [[British East India Company]]. After the company's [[Sepoy Rebellion of 1857|collapse]] in 1858, the islands were ceded to the [[British Raj]] as a crown colony. During the [[Second World War]], Singapore was [[Japanese occupation of Singapore|occupied by Japan]]. It gained independence from the UK in 1963 by federating with other former British territories to form [[Malaysia]], but separated two years later over [[Singapore in Malaysia|ideological differences]], becoming a sovereign nation in 1965. After early years of [[History of the Republic of Singapore#1965 to 1979|turbulence]] and despite lacking natural resources and a [[hinterland]], the nation developed rapidly as an [[Asian Tiger]] economy, based on external trade and its [[workforce]]. Singapore is a global hub for [[education]],{{cite news |last1=Coughlan |first1=Sean |title=Singapore first place in school rankings |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/education-38212070 |work=BBC News |date=6 December 2016}} [[entertainment]],{{cite news |title=Singapore's unlikely rise as a Southeast Asian entertainment hub |url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Location/Southeast-Asia/Singapore/Singapore-s-unlikely-rise-as-a-Southeast-Asian-entertainment-hub |work=Nikkei Asian Review}} [[finance]], [[Health care|healthcare]],{{cite news |last1=S. |first1=Ambili |title=Singapore healthiest Asian country; Italy tops global list despite economic crisis |url= http://www.ibtimes.sg/italy-named-worlds-healthiest-country-despite-economic-crisis-8576 |work=International Business Times, Singapore Edition |date=20 March 2017}} [[human capital]],{{cite news |title=Singapore's human capital most developed in Asia |url= https://www.straitstimes.com/business/economy/spores-human-capital-most-developed-in-asia |work=The Straits Times |date=13 September 2017 |location=Singapore}} [[innovation]],{{cite news |title=Singapore is fifth in 2018's Global Innovation Index |url= https://www.straitstimes.com/business/companies-markets/singapore-is-fifth-in-2018s-global-innovation-index |work=The Straits Times |date=11 July 2018 |location=Singapore}} [[logistics]],{{cite news |title=Road map to boost Singapore's role as global logistics hub |url= https://www.straitstimes.com/business/companies-markets/road-map-to-boost-singapores-role-as-global-logistics-hub |work=The Straits Times |date=17 November 2016 |location=Singapore}} [[manufacturing]],{{cite news |title=Singapore among 25 countries leading the world in advanced manufacturing: World Economic Forum |url= https://www.straitstimes.com/business/economy/singapore-among-25-countries-leading-the-world-in-advanced-manufacturing-world |work=The Straits Times |date=12 January 2018 |location= Singapore}} [[technology]],{{cite news |title=Sponsored: Singapore may be small, but it is quickly becoming a massive global tech hub |url= https://qz.com/921336/singapore-may-be-small-but-it-is-quickly-becoming-a-massive-global-tech-hub/ |work=Quartz}} [[tourism]],{{cite press release |title=Singapore tourism sector performance breaks record for the second year running in 2017 |url= https://www.stb.gov.sg/news-and-publications/lists/newsroom/dispform.aspx?ID=744 |publisher= Singapore Tourism Board |date=12 February 2018}} [[trade]], and [[transport hub|transport]].{{cite news |title= Singapore is world's best business hub after London: PwC |url= https://www.straitstimes.com/business/economy/spore-ranked-second-in-cities-of-opportunity-report |work=The Straits Times |date=7 September 2016 |location=Singapore}} The city ranks highly in [[International rankings of Singapore|numerous international rankings]], and has been recognized as the most "[[Global Information Technology Report|technology-ready]]" nation [[World Economic Forum|(WEF)]], top [[Union of International Associations|International-meetings city (UIA)]],{{cite press release |title=Singapore retains spot as World's Top International Meeting Country and City |url= https://www.stb.gov.sg/news-and-publications/lists/newsroom/dispform.aspx?ID=515 |date=27 June 2014 |publisher= Singapore Tourism Board}}{{cite news |title=Singapore is the top international meeting destination in the world again |url= https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/singapore-is-the-top-international-meeting-destination-in-the-world-again |work=The Straits Times |date=27 June 2014 |location= Singapore}} city with "best investment potential" (BERI), [[Smart city|world's smartest city]],{{cite news |title= Singapore best performing 'smart city' globally: Study |url= https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/singapore-best-performing-smart-city-globally-study-10038722 |work=Channel NewsAsia |location= Singapore |date=13 March 2018}} world's safest country,{{cite news |title=Singapore ranked safest country in the world, above Japan: Survey |url= http://www.asiaone.com/singapore/singapore-ranked-safest-country-world-above-japan-survey |work=AsiaOne |location= Singapore |date=24 May 2018}}{{cite news |title=Singaporeans feel safest in the world as country tops law and order index |url= https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/safe-singapore-tops-world-law-and-order-index|work=The Straits Times |location= Singapore |date=24 May 2018}} second-[[Global Competitiveness Report|most competitive country]], third-largest foreign exchange market, third-largest financial centre, third-largest oil refining and trading centre, fifth-most innovative country, and the second-busiest container port.{{cite news |title=Singapore is fifth in 2018's Global Innovation Index |url= https://www.straitstimes.com/business/companies-markets/singapore-is-fifth-in-2018s-global-innovation-index |work=The Straits Times |date=11 July 2018 |location= Singapore}} [[Economist Intelligence Unit|''The Economist'']] has ranked Singapore as the most expensive city to live in, since 2013.{{cite news |title=Asian and European cities compete for the title of most expensive city |url= https://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2018/03/daily-chart-9 |newspaper=The Economist |date=15 March 2018 |location= London |accessdate=21 April 2018}} It is identified as a [[tax haven]]. Singapore is the only country in Asia with an AAA sovereign rating from all major rating agencies, and [[List of countries by credit rating|one of 11 worldwide]]. Globally, the [[Port of Singapore]] and [[Changi Airport]] have held the titles of leading "Maritime Capital" and "Best Airport" respectively for consecutive years, while [[Singapore Airlines]] is the 2018 "World's Best Airline".{{cite news |title=SIA bags world's best airline title |url= https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/transport/sia-bags-worlds-best-airline-title |work=The Straits Times |date=18 July 2018 |location= Singapore}}{{cite news |title=Singapore takes top spot again as world's maritime capital: report |url= https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/transport/singapore-takes-top-spot-again-as-worlds-maritime-capital-report |work=Business Times |date=26 Apr 2017 |location= Singapore}} Singapore ranks 9th on the UN [[List of countries by Human Development Index|Human Development Index]] with the 3rd [[List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita|highest GDP per capita]]. It is placed highly in key social indicators: [[Education in Singapore|education]], [[Healthcare in Singapore|healthcare]], life expectancy, quality of life, personal safety and housing. Although [[List of countries by income equality|income inequality is high]], 90% of homes are owner-occupied. According to the [[Democracy Index]], the country is described as a "flawed democracy". The [[Singapore passport|Singaporean passport]] is joint first with Japan for visa-free travel granted by the most countries to its citizens.{{cite web|title=Global Ranking – Henley Passport Index 2018|url=https://www.henleypassportindex.com/passport-index|publisher=Henley & Partners|accessdate=1 July 2018}} The city-state is home to 5.6 million residents, 39% of whom are foreign nationals, including [[Permanent residency|permanent residents]]. There are four official [[Languages of Singapore|languages]]: [[English language|English]], [[Malay language|Malay]], [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin Chinese]], and [[Tamil language|Tamil]]; most Singaporeans are bilingual and English serves as the nation's [[lingua franca]]. Its [[cultural diversity]] is reflected in its extensive ethnic [[Singaporean cuisine|cuisine]] and major [[festivals]]. [[Pew Research]] has found that Singapore has the highest religious diversity of any country. [[Multiracialism]] has been enshrined in its constitution since independence, and continues to shape [[Race in Singapore|national policies]] in education, housing, politics, among others. Singapore is a [[Unitary state|unitary]] [[parliamentary republic]] with a [[Westminster system]] of [[Unicameralism|unicameral]] parliamentary government. The [[People's Action Party]] has won every election since self-government began in 1959. As one of the five founding members of [[ASEAN]], Singapore is the host of the [[Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation]] (APEC) Secretariat and [[Pacific Economic Cooperation Council|Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC)]] Secretariat,{{cite web |title=PECC - PECC :: The Pacific Economic Cooperation Council - International Secretariat |url=https://www.pecc.org/about/pecc-international-secretariat |website=www.pecc.org}} as well as many international conferences and events. It is also a member of the [[East Asia Summit]], [[Non-Aligned Movement]] and the [[Commonwealth of Nations]].{{cite news |title= Singapore remains top Asian city for meetings |url= https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/singapore-remains-top-asian-city-for-meetings |work=The Straits Times |date=9 September 2015 |location= Singapore}} ==Etymology== {{Main|Names of Singapore}} The English name of Singapore is an [[anglicisation]] of the native [[Malay language|Malay]] name for the country, ''{{lang|ms|Singapura}}'', which was in turn derived from [[Sanskrit]]{{cite web|url=http://www.bartleby.com/61/46/S0424600.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010411060419/http://www.bartleby.com/61/46/S0424600.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 April 2001 |title=Singapore |publisher=bartleby.com |accessdate=14 April 2006 |df=dmy-all }} ([[wikt:सिंहपुर|सिंहपुर]], [[International Alphabet of Sanskrit Transliteration|IAST]]: ''Siṃhapura''; ''siṃha'' is "lion", ''pura'' is "town" or "city"), hence the customary reference to the nation as the ''Lion City'', and its inclusion in many of the nation's symbols (e.g., its coat of arms, Merlion emblem). However, it is unlikely that [[lion]]s ever lived on the island; [[Sang Nila Utama]], the [[Srivijaya]]n prince said to have founded and named the island ''Singapura'', perhaps saw a [[Malayan tiger]]. There are however other suggestions for the origin of the name and scholars do not believe that the origin of the name is firmly established.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y9yvBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA22 |title=A History of Modern Singapore, 1819–2005 |author= C.M. Turnbull |pages=21–22 |publisher=NUS Press |date=30 October 2009|isbn= 978-9971694302 }}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bMt3BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA151|title=Singapore and the Silk Road of the Sea, 1300_1800|author= John N. Miksic |publisher=NUS Press |year= 2013|isbn= 978-9971695743|pages=151–152 }} The central island has also been called ''[[Pulau Ujong]]'' as far back as the third century CE, literally "island at the end" (of the [[Malay Peninsula]]) in Malay.{{cite web|title=Sang Nila Utama |website=Singapore Infopedia |publisher=National Library Board |url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_93_2005-01-26.html |date=2016 |accessdate=29 May 2017 }}Xu Yunqiao, History of South East Asia, 1961 Singapore World Publishing Co. 许云樵 《南洋史》 星洲世界书局 1961年 Singapore is also referred to as the ''Garden City'' for its tree-lined streets and greening efforts since independence,{{cite book|last1=inc|first1=Encyclopaedia britannica,|title=The New Encyclopædia Britannica|date=1991|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|location=Chicago, Ill.|isbn=978-0852295298|page=832|edition=15th|quote="Singapore, known variously as the 'Lion City,' or 'Garden City,' the latter for its many parks and tree-lined streets }}{{cite news|title=Singapore's nicknames|url=http://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/singapore-50-reasons|work=CNN|date=6 August 2015|quote="The Lion City. The Garden City. The Asian Tiger. The 'Fine' City. All venerable nicknames, but the longtime favorite is the 'Little Red Dot'"}} and the ''[[Little Red Dot]]'' for how the island-nation is depicted on many maps of the world and Asia, as a red dot.{{cite news |title=How Singapore gained its independence |url= https://www.economist.com/blogs/economist-explains/2015/03/economist-explains-22 |work=The Economist |date=6 August 2015 |quote="citizens of 'the little red dot'.." |location= London}}{{cite news |title=A little red dot in a sea of green |url= https://www.economist.com/news/special-report/21657610-sense-vulnerability-has-made-singapore-what-it-today-can-it-now-relax-bit |work=The Economist |date=16 July 2015 |quote="..with a characteristic mixture of pride and paranoia, Singapore adopted 'little red dot' as a motto" |location= London}}{{cite news |title= Editorial: The mighty red dot |url= http://www.thejakartapost.com/academia/2017/09/08/editorial-the-mighty-red-dot.html|work=The Jakarta Post |date=8 September 2017}} Also referred to as the "Switzerland of Asia" in 2017 due to its [[Neutral country|neutrality]] on international and regional issues.{{cite web|url=https://www.valuewalk.com/2017/05/the-switzerland-of-asia/|title=Singapore - The Switzerland of Asia|date=18 May 2017|publisher=|accessdate=21 September 2018}} ==History== {{Main|History of Singapore}} {| class="wikitable" style="background-color:LightSteelBlue; width:21em; font-size:90%; float:right; margin-right:1em" |- ! style="background-color:CornflowerBlue" | Historical affiliations |- | [[Srivijaya]] 650–1377 |- | [[Kingdom of Singapura]] 1299–1398 |- | [[Malacca Sultanate]] 1400–1511 |- | [[Johor Sultanate]] 1528–1819 |- | {{flagicon image|Flag of the United Kingdom.svg}} {{flagicon image|Flag of the British East India Company (1801).svg}} [[Founding of modern Singapore|Singapore under British control]] 1819–1826 |- | {{flagicon image|Flag of the British Straits Settlements (1874-1925).svg}} {{flagicon image|Flag of the British Straits Settlements (1925-1942).svg}} [[Singapore in the Straits Settlements|Straits Settlements]] 1826–1942 |- | {{flagicon image|Flag of Japan (1870–1999).svg}} {{flagicon image|War flag of the Imperial Japanese Army.svg}} [[Japanese occupation of Singapore]] 1942–1945 |- | {{flagicon image|Flag of the United Kingdom.svg}} [[British Military Administration (Malaya)|British Military Administration]] 1945–1946 |- | {{flagicon image|Flag of Singapore (1946-1959).svg}} [[Colony of Singapore]] 1946–1963 |- | {{flagicon image|Flag of Malaysia.svg}} [[Singapore in Malaysia]] 1963–1965 also known as [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]] |- | {{flagicon image|Flag of Singapore.svg}} Republic of Singapore 1965–present |} ===Ancient Singapore=== The Greco-Roman astronomer [[Ptolemy]] (90{{ndash}}168) identified a place called ''Sabana'' in the general area in the second century,{{cite web|last=Hack |first=Karl |url=http://www.hsse.nie.edu.sg/staff/kahack/cc%202.3%20(Little%20India).htm |title=Records of Ancient Links between India and Singapore |publisher=National Institute of Education, Singapore |accessdate=4 August 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060426231828/http://www.hsse.nie.edu.sg/staff/kahack/cc%202.3%20%28Little%20India%29.htm |archivedate=26 April 2006 |df=dmy-all }} and the earliest written record of Singapore occurs in a Chinese account from the third century, describing the island of ''Pu Luo Chung'' ([[wikt:蒲|蒲]] [[wikt:罗|罗]] [[wikt:中|中]]). This was itself a transliteration from the [[Malay language|Malay]] name ''"[[Pulau Ujong]]"'', or "island at the end" (of the [[Malay Peninsula]]).{{cite web| title = Singapore: History, Singapore 1994 | url = http://inic.utexas.edu/asnic/countries/singapore/Singapore-History.html | publisher=Asian Studies @ University of Texas at Austin | accessdate =7 July 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070323095958/http://inic.utexas.edu/asnic/countries/Singapore/Singapore-History.html |archivedate = 23 March 2007|deadurl=yes}} The [[Nagarakretagama]], a [[Java (island)|Javanese]] epic poem written in 1365, referred to a settlement on the island called ''[[Temasek|Tumasik]]'' (possibly meaning "Sea Town").{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DTOJAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA381#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Singapore Street Names: A Study of Toponymics|authors= Victor R Savage, Brenda Yeoh |publisher=Marshall Cavendish |date= 15 June 2013 |isbn=978-9814484749 |page=381}}In 1299, according to the ''[[Malay Annals]]'', the [[Kingdom of Singapura]] was founded on the island by [[Sang Nila Utama]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J9JAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA43 |title=Malay Annals |page=43 |author=Dr John Leyden and Sir Thomas Stamford Rffles|date=1821 }} Although the historicity of the accounts as given in the ''Malay Annals'' is the subject of academic debates,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bMt3BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA154#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Singapore and the Silk Road of the Sea, 1300_1800 |author= John N. Miksic |page=154 |publisher= NUS Press |date= 15 November 2013|isbn= 978-9971695743 }} it is nevertheless known from various documents that Singapore in the 14th century, then known as [[Temasek]], was a trading port under the influence of both the [[Majapahit]] Empire and the [[Ayutthaya Kingdom|Siamese]] kingdoms{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bMt3BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA184#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Singapore and the Silk Road of the Sea, 1300–1800|author= John N. Miksic |publisher=NUS Press |date=15 November 2013|isbn= 978-9971695743|pages=183–185 }} and was a part of the [[Indosphere]]Robert M.W. Dixon, Y.
